qas.question: How does the pain signal travel from the periphery to the spinal cord?

answers.text: along an A-delta or C fiber

qas.question: What is the electrically insulting material that sheaths a-delta fiber?
What is pain evoked by a-delta fibers described as?
How do first order neurons enter the spinal cord?
What travels along a C-delta or A fiber?
What is the name for an insulating material?
What is evoked by the faster C deltas?

context: The <b5_0>pain signal<b5_0/> travels from the periphery to the spinal cord <a0_0>along an A-delta or C fiber<a0_0/>. Because the <a1_0>A-delta<a1_0/> fiber is thicker than the C fiber, and is thinly sheathed in an electrically insulating material (<a2_0><b6_0>myelin<b6_0/><a2_0/>), it carries its signal faster (5–30 m/s) than the unmyelinated C fiber (0.5–2 m/s). <b7_0>Pain<b7_0/> evoked by the (faster) A-delta fibers is described as <a3_0>sharp and is felt first<a3_0/>. This is followed by a <b8_0>duller pain<b8_0/>, often described as burning, carried by the C fibers. These first order neurons enter the spinal cord <a4_0>via Lissauer's tract<a4_0/>.
